availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Alfred Lawrence Shotwell (Jefferson Co, KY, Owner of an enslaved person, Tamar [Unknown] until 1851.)

body.p: Jefferson County, Kentucky, merchant. Mason County, Kentucky, native. Married to Gabriella Shotwell. Father of Stephen Breckinridge Shotwell, W. Preston Shotwell, Betty T. Shotwell, Alfred Ann Shotwell, Fanny T. Shotwell, and John Shotwell. Merchant in Louisville, Kentucky, in 1850. Enslaved Tamar [Unknown], in Louisville in 1851. Commission merchant in Louisville in 1860. Owned four enslaved persons and employed one enslaved person in Louisville in 1860.

ab.bibl:
Seventh Manuscript Census of the United States (1850), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, District 3, p. 255B.
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville, 5th Ward, p. .
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Slave Schedules, Kentucky, Jefferson County, Louisville, 5th Ward, p. 135.
"Alfred Lawrence Shotwell (1809-1893)," Find A Grave, Memorial #96567038, accessed December 1, 2021, https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/96567038.
J. Blaine Hudson, Fugitive Slaves and the Underground Railroad in Kentucky (Jefferson, NC: McFarland and Co, 2011), 134-35.
Rev. Calvin Fairbank During Slavery Times: How He “Fought the Good Fight” to Prepare “The Way”; Edited from His Manuscript (Chicago, IL: R. R. McCabe & Co., 1890), 85-92.
